text: <@U015UNF0LSV> There are several next gen language projects that are aimed directly at cross-platform graphical interactive software development. The "Red" language (a rebirth of Rebol) is aiming for a very wide range, and my Beads language does Web, Mac OSX, Windows, iOS and Android.  Not sure what you mean by 3 big OS'es, because there are really 5 economically important programming OSes nowadays, each with millions of users. I am leaving out internet of things as it is not usually graphical/interactive, and ignoring Linux desktop because Android is 100x larger than Linux desktop economically and due to the fascistic "software IP must be free", there is no appreciable market for Linux desktop software. It is quite unfortunate that Stallman and his ilk so beat down vendors of linux products that they drove them off to greener pastures.  There is also a lamentable lack of standardization on Linux executable formats and graphical layers that greatly hindered a Linux ecosystem from developing commercially. For my own project i am using Node.JS or Deno to run JS for Linux server side code. Sure would be nice if Google would just let Android take over the Linux desktop market, and make things uniform.

text: FWIW, I've often thought about doing a VR extension to my live coding work.  It would be really cool to be 'inside' the generated scene.  That's another reason for my custom text editor on top of the graphics device; so I can embed it in the environment in interesting ways.

text:
My current temptation is to try and marry Clojure (or some other lispy interactive thing I like) with the Godot engine :eyes: it looks like the exact kind of base I’m looking for.

I’m also thinking of building a VM for this, I’ve always wanted to write a language, why not have the input be visual / draggable rather than text. It’s still an AST, just not text.

text: Janet looks really interesting.  This video is from yesterday, when I started bringing up some scripting for my Node Graph.  I'm currently using Chibi Scheme.  I like the simplicty/syntax of Janet though.  Hmm.

elements.text: Janet looks really interesting.  This video is from yesterday, when I started bringing up some scripting for my Node Graph.  I'm currently using Chibi Scheme.  I like the simplicty/syntax of Janet though.  Hmm.

text:
Yeah, janet is really nice. There’s also fennel which is really similar and by the same author <https://fennel-lang.org/>

That’s what Conjure is written in, it compiles to lua so Neovim can execute it directly inside it’s own process.

elements.text: Yeah, janet is really nice. There’s also fennel which is really similar and by the same author
That’s what Conjure is written in, it compiles to lua so Neovim can execute it directly inside it’s own process.

text: Janet/fennel have a feel of diet Clojure to them.

elements.text: Janet/fennel have a feel of diet Clojure to them.

text: Read is targeting block chain technology as its home base. But the project is well funded and will eventually spread to all platforms. There is also dart which Originally landed with a thud, But the flutter cross platform graphics library has so much manpower in it that it is now quite usable. Flutter is unique in that it renders to bitmap and then transfers a bitmap to the underlying operating system. In the case of beer is it operates as a transpiler to JavaScript, So in some sense it is a direct competitor of typescript

elements.text: Read is targeting block chain technology as its home base. But the project is well funded and will eventually spread to all platforms. There is also dart which Originally landed with a thud, But the flutter cross platform graphics library has so much manpower in it that it is now quite usable. Flutter is unique in that it renders to bitmap and then transfers a bitmap to the underlying operating system. In the case of beer is it operates as a transpiler to JavaScript, So in some sense it is a direct competitor of typescript

text:
I went to school for game development, but I don't actually work in the games industry now. It's just something I do off and on for fun. 

A few years back I tended to work mostly with Unity, but the parts or Unity I enjoyed seem to have stagnated, so I try to avoid it these days.

In particular, I'm interested in game networking and using the GPU for non-graphics simulation. 

As it pertains to this slack community, I find gpgpu programming particularly interesting. It's a space where there's a real need to move beyond C inspired programming languages that also has very hard performance requirements.

elements.text:

text: <@U01448TH3PG> what I had in mind is for the apps to be easy to build (no dependencies hell), be performant and look good. One should also be able to implement the said app in both a high level declarative language (like Elm) but also be able to get down to lower level language if performance requirements need it.

elements.text: what I had in mind is for the apps to be easy to build (no dependencies hell), be performant and look good. One should also be able to implement the said app in both a high level declarative language (like Elm) but also be able to get down to lower level language if performance requirements need it.

text:
one of the problems with no code (and frameworks too, though not as strongly) is that if a project is successful, it will outgrow the initial platform on which its built. In the case of a framework, you can do a rewrite that still re-uses a lot of the existing code. In the case of a no-code platform, you have to rewrite from scratch.
The problem is that success for a lot of projects doesn't necessarily mean that there is money for a team of professional developers to rewrite. Success might mean that a no-code app is heavily relied upon internally, but the company couldn't afford to rewrite it.
No-code tools generally solve the problem of writing the code. But that's often all they solve. Syntax is not the hard part of coding (after a few months). The hard part is keeping things well organised and adaptable.
When a regular codebase gets out of hand, the code can be analysed and refactored with the help of tools. When a no-code app gets out of hand, :man-shrugging: . (I predict a healthy industry of useless no-code consultants that will help companies "maintain" no-code apps whilst making things worse, in about 5-10 years' time. Just look at sharepoint.)

I'm even hoping to have back-and-forth. If a developer writes code that adheres to the FP JS subset, I can generate a visual representation of it (the visual rep is just a projection of the AST, much like e.g. Prettier just projects the AST).
This would change no-code from a binary proposition (either yes or no), to a spectrum.
Citizen devs can make most of the "boring" parts of the app, and call in a pro when they get stuck. The pro can use the interface she's used to (text). It won't be a choice between sticking with a no-code ball of mud, or an expensive complete rewrite by a team of devs. Each party can play to their strengths.

If its not inheritable, it represents a lot of risk to companies. Vendor lock-in risk, rewrite risk, etc. which makes it less appealing. Knowing you can hit eject (or not even eject, but add a pro dev to a citizen dev team), will be an attractive proposition, and as you said, can also be used as a prototyping tool.
